newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Khmer Rouge hardliners slam MFN for Cambodia.
newsitem.headline: Khmer Rouge hardliners slam MFN for Cambodia.

text.p: Khmer Rouge hardliners attacked U.S. President Bill Clinton on Saturday for granting Cambodia Most Favoured Nation (MFN) trading privileges, saying it was an election ploy.

"Why did Bill Clinton do this? Clinton did this for propaganda, to collect votes from Cambodian people who are living in America for the next American presidential election," Khmer Rouge radio said in a broadcast monitored in Phnom Penh.
U.S. President Clinton on Wednesday signed a bill granting Cambodia MFN status, declaring it would help establish democracy and economic reforms in the country.
MFN status reduces taxes on hundreds of exports to the United States. It also expands opportunities for U.S. business and investment.
Khmer Rouge radio, which is controlled by hardliners, said the Clinton administration had failed to mention alleged human rights abuses and violations of democracy by the Phnom Penh.

The Maoist Khmer Rouge, which has been fighting the government since boycotting U.N-run elections in 1993, split last month with followers of former foreign minister Ieng Sary who is talking peace with the government.
